title: Is there any Western instrument that is similar to Japanese koto? - Quora

response.answer_text: In America “Autoharps” and the like along with both kinds of dulcimers would be considered zithers along with koto. Zithers have strings parallel to the sound box and no neck. Harps are not in the same family because they have strings perpendicular to the sound box. Koto is part of the “Asian Long Curved Zither” subfamily. They differ from other zither in you move the bridges mostly to tune (some require both moving the bridges and turning each string). And that left hand technique is used extensively to modify the pitch, and for special effects on the left (not playing side) of the bridge.

Sure, Latvian kokle:  And its ancient variants, even more similar to koto:  Also Finnish kantele, which is essentially same, but tends to be smaller than kokle:  Also Russian gusli, where the principle is similar, but playing style and shape, as well as string attachment differs.
